LAC (a Vancouver based company) that is trying to develop the Thacker Pass lithium reserves is embarking on a major science experiment of trying to extract lithium from clay deposits. Likewise, CTR (an Australian firm) is in California's 'Salton Sea' for the past decade, again, embarking on another major science experiment of trying to extract lithium using DLE from salt brines. Neither operations have been proven on a 'large scale'. 30 years ago America had like 90% of the supply of lithium. Within the past few years, US's share of the pie had dropped to a whopping 2%. Why? What does Australia and Chile have in common? Australia produces over 50% of the global supply of lithium, which is done purely by hard rock spoduemene. In Chile, (or the lithium triangle there) supply a good portion of say 40%, which is done purely by extracting lithium from the brine salars through evaporation. 

If America is going to have a lithium market of it's own, raw material has to be imported and refined. But it's a dirty process and the environmentalists have this NIMBY problem. Which is why China owns the supply chain and refining. 

Biden just passed a 100% tax on Chinese EV imports into America. While places like NZ (who have free trade with China), and Australia, have opened the door on Chinese brand EVs.

LITHIUM (PRICE | SUPPLY | DEMAND) FORECA.summary:
<guideline>
주요내용: 리튬 수요와 공급 전망

내용:

- 미국의 리튬 수요가 2030년까지 약 500% 증가할 것으로 예상됨. 이는 주로 전기차 수요 증가에 따른 것임.
- 리튬 가격은 최근 크게 하락했지만, 향후 수요 증가로 인해 다시 상승할 것으로 예상됨. 전문가들은 리튬 가격이 평균 $445,000/톤 수준까지 회복될 것으로 전망함.
- 2030년까지 전 세계적으로 리튬 수요가 1,500% 이상 증가할 것으로 예상되며, 이를 충족하기 위해서는 70개 이상의 새로운 리튬 광산이 필요할 것으로 보임.

수요/공급에 대한 영향: 수요 증가 - 전기차 수요 증가 // 공급 증가 필요 - 수요 증가에 따른 공급 부족 우려

</guideline>

HL_summary.주요내용: 리튬 수요가 급증할 것으로 예상되며, 2030년까지 240만 톤, 2035년까지 380만 톤의 리튬 탄산염이 필요할 것으로 전망됩니다.
내용: 전기 자동차 보급 및 에너지 저장 기술의 급속한 성장으로 인해 리튬 수요가 증가할 것으로 예상됩니다.
전문가들은 현재 8%에서 2030년까지 미국에서 판매되는 자동차의 50-75%가 전기 자동차가 될 것으로 예측하고 있습니다.
배터리 기술 발전과 미국 인플레이션 감축법 (Inflation Reduction Act)으로 인해 향후 5년 내 전기 자동차 가격이 30-40% 하락할 것으로 예상됩니다.
리튬 가격은 평균 톤당 445,000달러 수준으로 회복될 것으로 예측되어, 특히 호주 광산 부문의 리튬 주식에 유망한 투자 기회가 될 것으로 보입니다.
HL_summary.수요/공급에 대한 영향: 전기 자동차 및 에너지 저장 기술의 급격한 성장으로 인해 리튬 수요가 크게 증가할 것으로 예상됩니다. 배터리 기술 발전과 정부 정책으로 인해 전기 자동차 가격이 하락하면서 수요가 더욱 늘어날 것으로 보입니다. 이에 따라 리튬 가격도 회복될 것으로 전망되어 관련 산업에 긍정적인 영향을 미칠 것으로 예상됩니다.

LITHIUM (PRICE | SUPPLY | DEMAND) FORECA.summary:
<guideline>
주요내용: E3 Lithium은 캐나다 최대 규모의 리튬 자원을 보유하고 있으며, 알버타에서 리튬 추출 기술을 개발하여 2026년 상업 생산을 목표로 하고 있다.

내용:

- E3 Lithium은 캐나다에서 가장 큰 리튬 자원을 보유하고 있으며, 16백만 톤의 측정 및 지시 자원을 가지고 있다. 이는 캐나다 전체 자원의 5배 규모이다.
- E3 Lithium은 알버타에서 리튬을 추출하기 위한 기술을 개발했으며, 현재 파일럿 테스트를 완료하고 상업 생산을 위한 준비를 하고 있다.
- E3 Lithium은 알버타의 규제 환경과 인프라를 활용하여 지속가능하고 효율적인 방식으로 리튬을 생산할 계획이다. 이를 통해 리튬 공급망의 안정성과 지속가능성을 높일 수 있다.
- E3 Lithium은 전기차 및 에너지 저장 시스템 수요 증가로 인한 리튬 시장 성장 기회를 활용하고자 한다.
- E3 Lithium은 현재 전처리 공정 개발, 예비 타당성 조사 완료, 상업 생산을 위한 프로젝트 파이낸싱 등을 진행 중이며, 2026년 상업 생산을 목표로 하고 있다.

수요/공급에 대한 영향: 리튬 수요 증가 - 전기차 및 에너지 저장 시스템 수요 증가 // 리튬 공급 증가 - E3 Lithium의 16백만 톤 규모 리튬 자원 확보 및 상업 생산 계획
</guideline>

주요내용: 리튬 시장의 공급 증가와 수요 증가 전망

내용:

- 세계 최대 규모의 리튬 매장지가 발견되었으며, 이를 개발할 작은 규모의 기업이 있음
- 이 기업은 기존 기업들과 다른 리튬 추출 기술을 사용하여 24시간 내에 배터리 등급의 리튬을 생산할 수 있음
- 이 기업은 리튬 Americas Corp.이며, 미국 에너지부로부터 26억 달러의 조건부 대출을 받아 ther pass 프로젝트를 진행 중임
- 리튬 Americas Corp.은 아직 초기 단계의 광산 운영 기업이지만, 향후 전기차 배터리 시장 성장에 따른 기회가 있을 것으로 기대됨

수요/공급에 대한 영향: 리튬 시장의 공급 증가 - 새로운 기술과 대규모 매장지 개발로 인한 공급 증가 // 리튬 시장의 수요 증가 - 전기차 배터리 시장 성장으로 인한 수요 증가
</guideline>

LITHIUM (PRICE | SUPPLY | DEMAND) FORECA.summary:
<guideline>
주요내용: 리튬 유니버스(LU7)가 캐나다 퀘벡에 리튬 정제 공장을 건설하여 북미 지역의 리튬 공급 및 수요 격차를 해소하려는 전략을 가지고 있음.

내용:
- 리튬 유니버스는 경험 많은 팀을 보유하고 있으며, 정부 및 금융 지원을 받을 것으로 기대하고 있음.
- 대서양 회랑 지역의 스페오딩 광산들과 협력하여 원료 공급을 확보하고, 안정적인 오프테이크 계약 체결을 목표로 하고 있음.
- 퀘벡의 베컹코어 산업단지에 공장을 건설할 예정이며, 기존 인프라와 자원, 인력을 활용할 수 있는 장점이 있음.
- 환경 및 지역사회 영향 관리, 숙련된 인력 확보 등의 과제가 있지만, 리튬 유니버스는 이를 해결하기 위한 계획을 가지고 있음.

수요/공급에 대한 영향: 수요 증가 - 북미 시장의 리튬 수요 증가에 대응하기 위한 전략 // 공급 증가 - 리튬 유니버스의 정제 공장 건설을 통해 북미 지역의 리튬 공급 확대 예상
</guideline>

<guideline>
주요내용: 리튬 시장의 수요와 공급 전망

내용:

- 현재 리튬 탄산염 현물 가격은 중국 시장의 소량 거래에 의해 결정되고 있으나, 향후 4-5년 내 공급 부족이 예상됨
- 2028년 이후의 리튬 가격이 더 중요할 것으로 보임
- Lake Resources는 아르헨티나에서 전력 공급 계약을 체결하고 전략적 파트너십 프로세스를 진행 중이며, 장기 공급 계약 체결을 목표로 하고 있음
- 아르헨티나의 새로운 대통령이 비즈니스 친화적인 정책을 추진하고 있어 Lake Resources와 전체 리튬 산업에 긍정적인 영향을 줄 것으로 기대됨
- 미국의 배터리 제조 시설 증가에도 불구하고 원료 공급이 부족한 상황이며, Lake Resources와 같은 대규모 프로젝트가 이 문제를 해결하는 데 도움이 될 것으로 기대됨

수요/공급에 대한 영향: 리튬 시장의 공급 부족 - 향후 4-5년 내 공급 부족이 예상되어 2028년 이후 리튬 가격이 더 중요해질 것으로 보임 // 리튬 시장의 수요 증가 - 미국의 배터리 제조 시설 증가로 인한 원료 수요 증가
</guideline>

snippet.title: Executive Series 9 May 24: Patriot Battery Metals (PMT) CEO, Ken Brinsden
snippet.description: Patriot Battery Metals (PMT) CEO, Ken Brinsden speaks with Tom Piotrowski about the lithium industry's outlook & its Corvette ...

caption.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

TOM PIOTROWSKI: Thanks
for joining us today.

I am speaking with
Ken Brinsden, who

is the CEO of Patriot
Battery Metals.

Ken, David Letterman
on Netflix does

a series called my next guest
requires no introduction
or something along those lines.

And for anyone who has followed
the lithium story in Australia

in recent years, you will
be very familiar to them.

So thank you very much
for making the time today.

KEN BRINSDEN: Oh,
it's my pleasure, Tom.
Nice to be with you.

TOM PIOTROWSKI: So we've
got so much to talk about.

So why don't we perhaps start
out with the bigger picture?

Because there's probably no
better individual to talk

about where we are at the moment
in terms of the lithium story

broadly, what's happening
in relation to pricing,

and the volatility that we
have seen in recent years.

There has been quite
disheartening for people
who might hold lithium shares.

How are you reflecting on
what's happened in recent years?

KEN BRINSDEN: Yeah, the
volatility, I can imagine,

is confusing for
everybody, especially

those that hold shares
in the lithium world.

I guess my overriding message
would be, don't lose heart.

This industry still
has a long way to go.

The last decade, it was really
about China and the growth

and actually even more
than that, their dominance
of the industry.

So lithium raw
materials was always
going to be a China story.

But it's fair to say it's
now about global growth,

but in particular,
the US and Europe.
And I think it's their decade.

And all the evidence points
to significant growth

in those markets because the
battery manufacturing facilities

are either in or
under construction.

There's active work in the
chemicals in the supply chain.

And that's now motivating
a lot of discussion

about localization
of raw materials.

And that's really where Patriot
and the Corvette discovery
starts to become material.

Because it's a good
enough quality product,

serious scale,
underwriting potential

for decades in those
new chemical facilities.

So for us, that's a really
important market development.

As successful as growth
was going into China,

and still is today,
really there's

a lot more to happen in the
US and Europe, in which case,

that's exactly what
we're setting up for.

TOM PIOTROWSKI: So I suppose
the other important aspect

is the development of the market
for lithium in particular.

And it's-- even though the
story seems to have been around

for a while, lithium,
in terms of its pricing,

its transparency, and all
of those things, liquidity,

it's still in its infancy
in relative terms, isn't it?
KEN BRINSDEN: It is.
Yeah.
No, that's so true.

And being a specialty
chemical, it

has that sort of added nuance
about the quality in the product
being a really key driver.
But it's not all--
it's not all that bad.
It's getting better.

I think about the last
decade, I would say, no.

There has been some useful
market developments, a bit more

public transparency in things
like auctioning product,

the price reporting
agencies getting

a bit more sophisticated
about the way
they differentiate product.

The next development, which
I think is really important,

is about transparency, but
especially in western markets.

And this is an area where
there is a bit of weakness,

but moves afoot to
continue to shine

a light on what's the price
going into Japan and Korea.

And it might
surprise your viewers

to understand that actually,
the price in Japan and Korea

today is materially higher
than the prices in China.

And it's typically
motivated by a quality.

A different quality paradigm
exists in those markets.

So I'd really like to see a
lot more sort of light shone

onto those pricing
dynamics, which

I'm comfortable is heading
in the right direction.

We've just got a
little ways to go.

TOM PIOTROWSKI: I saw
headlines late last year

that were attributed to you
in terms of your observations

that the lithium pricing
was beginning to bottom out.

And here we are
several months hence

and the dynamics have
improved considerably.
What do you put that down to?

KEN BRINSDEN: Yeah, the market
today is motivated by China.

And China had gone through
a period of destocking.
And it was pretty aggressive.

And that's what's impacted
the rest of the supply chain.

But actually, it happened
with respect to cells.

Sounds kind of weird,
but China had--
TOM PIOTROWSKI: Batteries.

Like a lot of batteries
have been stockpiled.
KEN BRINSDEN: Exactly.
Yep, that's exactly right.

And especially, a particular
subset of the batteries

called the LFP, or lithium
iron phosphate batteries,

China had gone really hard in
their development and expansion
capacity.

And unfortunately,
they were sitting

on a few cells, which
were a trigger for, let's

stop manufacturing them, sell
the cells that are in stock,

and then we'll come
back to the market.

And I'm pleased to say that
that's starting to happen,
probably has a ways to go.

China can't stand out of the
raw materials market forever.

I would say when they
step back into the market,

you can see-- you would expect
to see a reasonable price
response.

But the influence
of China, I think,

is also something
to keep an eye on.

Because there is more
development happening

in the west, you'll start
to see more price motivation

with a global kind
of perspective as

compared to equities focusing so
much on China, which is really
what's happening today.

But this is the
natural evolution

of an industry that's
growing very quickly.

And that's one of the reasons
why the cycles can be very
fast as well and aggressive.
Yeah, exactly.

So if you're an equity
investor, my advice

would be, hang in there because
today's market conditions are

clearly to the downside
and not normal,

something that would look a
lot more normal as pricing 30,
40, 50%, even 100% from here.

So let's look forward
to that when it happens.

TOM PIOTROWSKI: Let's talk
about the Corvette resource.

That is your primary
focus at Patriot.

So just in days gone by,
you've had an upgrade
in terms of that resource.

You have-- you've compared
this to Pilgangoora

in terms of being one of
the most significant lithium
resources globally.

KEN BRINSDEN: Yeah, I'm really
excited about the potential
in Corvette.

Actually, well beyond probably
what we've talked about today.

It's an amazing
piece of geology.

And that goes back
to the inception

of getting involved
there in the first place.

Just an observation that
this is different geology.

It's got the potential
for some serious scale.

And it's both the
scale and the grade,

or the tenor of the
geology, that's been exposed
in the last couple of years.

And that's what's
now got us more

serious about the
development cycle,

moving from just being about
exploration to saying, no.

This has all the
hallmarks of being a--
one of the great minds.

We should get on with
the development story.

Now, I say all
that, but would also

make the point that we've
really only just started
from a drilling point of view.

There is so much more
potential to be realised there.

And that's also going to be
one of our key objectives.

This is a province
scale discovery.

It's not just about the
work in CD5 or even in CD13.

We'd be pretty
confident in saying

there's a lot more lithium
to be discovered at Corvette.

TOM PIOTROWSKI: In terms
of its positioning,

you've got the proximity to
the North American market.

You've got established
infrastructure,

I suppose, in the
James Bay area.
But I suppose it is in Canada.

Just you get a lot of
water up there, don't you?
KEN BRINSDEN: Yeah, exactly.

That does-- it's a
lot of conversation
in Australia about the water.
Yeah.
TOM PIOTROWSKI: Right.

KEN BRINSDEN: And yeah,
it's a valid inquiry.

So the glacial events that
occur in that part of the world

have scoured the Earth and
left shallow depressions.

And it's those
shallow depressions

that fill with the water,
and as the snow melts.

That's where the
water comes from.
And there's a lot of them.

Perversely, the very fact
that there's a lot of them

means that not that many of them
are actually that sensitive.
TOM PIOTROWSKI: Right.

KEN BRINSDEN: So it's true
that in the development

of a mine at Corvette, we
would likely disturb the lake.

But that itself in Canada is
far from a barrier to mining.

In fact, there would be the
majority of the mines developed

in Canada that are
impacting water
in some way, shape, or form.

That's equally true immediately
around us in the James Bay
region.

And there's heaps of
precedent for approval.
So we're not concerned about it.
It's just due process.

That doesn't mean we're
flippant about it.

But at the same time, it's
done for just about every mine,

in which case, we'd
expect ours to-- as long

as we'd been disciplined, and
done good work, that it'll

pass in good order as part
of the mines development.

TOM PIOTROWSKI:
Because you've said

that the permitting process
in Canada in general

is quite different to what you
might encounter in local terms,
for example.

KEN BRINSDEN: Yeah, so the
comparison I really like to draw

is to say that when
you're developing

a mine in Quebec, but especially
in the James bay region,

it's really solid from the
point of view of process
to motivate approvals.

It's not New South
Wales and Victoria,

which are notoriously difficult
places to build a mine.

It's a lot more like
Western Australia.

A culture, a background of
mining, the Cree, the First

Nations have been involved
in mine developments

over multiple
decades, in which case

the combination of community
engagement and due process

in the approvals
process is really solid.

It all stems from
the treaty that

was signed between the Cree
in the James Bay region
and the province of Quebec.

And what they established was
a really sophisticated system

for development of
projects in the north that

started with the
hydroelectric scheme,

and subsequently has led to
many, many more developments

in the central region and
northern regions of Quebec

in the James Bay territory
as per the treaty.

And it's a really
key tool to get
a mine developed in good order.

And the relationship with
the Cree is really important.
So that part of it is a--

if you're going to be a good
sophisticated mining company,

you should have your
consultation 100%
and truly partner with the Cree.

And if so, you can
expect your mine
to be developed in good order.

TOM PIOTROWSKI:
Now, one thing that

stands out very conspicuously
in recent months is

Albemarle popping up
on the share register.

There was a bit of a
land rush late last year

in terms of Albemarle
particularly featuring
in a couple of stories.

They got locked out of an
opportunity here in Australia.

And they've popped
up on your register.

Tell me about how
you feel about that,

and indeed what sort
of conversations

you've had with the world's
most important lithium miner.
KEN BRINSDEN: Yeah.

Yeah, they're a really credible
counterparty, aren't they?

They've been a first mover
in the west for development

of chemical
initiatives in lithium.

And of course, they have a
big multinational business
in lithium chemicals.

And we've enjoyed the
relationship with them.

So a constructive
negotiation to have them

participate as a
shareholder in Patriot.

And in return, we'd
facilitate the discussion

about linking mine capacity,
a certain subset of the mine

capacity, to chemical
initiatives in North America.

And we've really enjoyed the
relationship with Albemarle.

And we'd hope that
they have as well.

Now, as it stands, we've
still got more work

to do with them as
to ultimately what we

do to connect the mine
and the chemical facility.

But at this point in time,
nothing commercial locked down.

It's all dealt with
at a memorandum
of understanding level.

But a constructive
relationship, nonetheless.

The other observation
I'd make is

that in thinking about
chemicals and raw materials

for North America
and Europe, there

is a new level of
engagement going on

in industry to support the
development of those new supply
chains.

And a couple of key
things are motivating it.

The first is the growth
that I alluded to.

The US and Europe are going
to be really important sources

of demand as they continue to
develop battery facilities,

basically growing into the new
energy industry of which EVs
are an important part.

But the other key issue is the
geopolitics of the industry
and the dominance of China.

So the conversation has pretty
quickly turned to, what does it

take to localise
these industries?

And that's motivating a new
level of conversation as well.

So the backdrop there
is things like the IRA

and government
motivating capital

to support the development of
these alternate supply chains.

TOM PIOTROWSKI:
You're not talking
about the Irish Republican Army.

Of course, you're talking
about the Inflation Reduction
Act in the United States.
KEN BRINSDEN: Yeah, exactly.

And what that's forcing is kind
of a different conversation

about who participates, and
where do they do it from.

And the good news is
that that localization
seems highly likely to occur.

And it'll be motivated by the
dominance of China and the need

to continue to differentiate
the industry and the lithium ion
battery supply chain especially.

TOM PIOTROWSKI: Thinking about
the important stakeholder

relationships that you built
when you were at Pilbara
with Ganfeng, with CATL.

And I'm just wondering,
is that a similar playbook

that you're applying in terms
of Albemarle at the moment

and what that might
lead to in the future?

KEN BRINSDEN: Yeah, that's
a fair observation, Tom.
Yeah.

Partners in the
industry are a big part

of the development
of this new industry.
It requires a lot of capital.

It requires very
intricate relationships,

supplier-to-customer
relationships.

But in this instance, as much
as my experience at Pilbara

Minerals was all about
Pilgangoora and China,

in this case, it's
more about, what does,

or what's the capacity,
for Patriot and Corvette

to interconnect with
western interests?

And it's definitely the case
that some of those relationships

are value adding from
the Pilbara history,

but also that there's
new relationships

to be developed to
support the west,

and the US, and hence Albemarle
kind of rising to the fore.

But they're not the only one
that are actively investing.

So more important relationships
or additive relationships
with the likes of, say, Korea.

Korea has those
deep ties to the US.

And industrially, they're
kind of very active.

And in particular, in the
lithium ion battery industry,

given the Koreans are the
next big mover beyond China.

TOM PIOTROWSKI: The
other thing that

has been a feature of
the lithium landscape

in recent times has been a more
cautious approach from a banking

perspective in terms of
the banking side of things

supporting new initiatives when
it comes to lithium because
of the volatility.

How have you found the
appetite amongst bankers

when it comes to
conversations that you've had?

KEN BRINSDEN: Yeah, I reflect--
when this question gets asked,

I reflect on where
we were in June 2020.

It was the lowest of the
lows in the lithium market,
at least at the time.

And it was tough, really
hard to do business.

And yet exactly at
that time was when we
refinanced with western banks.

We got out of a bond instrument
and into a more sophisticated--

TOM PIOTROWSKI: And
onerous bond instrument.
KEN BRINSDEN: Exactly.
Yeah, no.

One that was tough on us with
a much more sophisticated sort

of project development
and western bank interests

supporting it in that case, Soc
Gen and the Clean Energy Finance
Corporation.

But that was the lowest
price that lithium
had been for about a decade.
Here we are.

TOM PIOTROWSKI: What could they
see in that moment that perhaps
a lot of others didn't?
KEN BRINSDEN: No, exactly.

And I think this
is where perhaps

the industry and investors
should have some faith.

This lithium ion
battery growth story
has probably decades to run.

It'll be the rechargeable
battery of choice.

Now, I know there's always
lots of conversation about what
the alternative could be.

But there is no doubt in my mind
that the lithium ion battery
wins for about a generation.

And the reason that
happens is, perversely,

because the lithium
ion batteries still has
a lot of perfection to come.

The technology is going
to continue to improve.

And that fundamentally lowers
the cost of the technology.

So if you've got a new
battery technology to deploy,

you're not competing
against today's cost.

You're competing
against the cost
of those batteries in a decade.

And they're already
significantly cheaper.

So I feel like with
that as a backdrop,

you can be confident
in the growth story.

And that's where the banks got
their interest from at the time

just to say, OK, it's tough,
Pilgangoora is a good mine.

Should it be in
production for the life

cycle of their instrument
and more to come?
The answer is yes.

So with all of that
in the background,

Corvette is a good
enough project

that it's going to
attract similar interest.

But arguably, it's easier
today because the motivation

in the supply chain
for the US is stronger.

And potentially, governments
are now acting, saying,

well, we need this
industry, so we're

going to actively
deploy capital as well.

A combination of those
things gives me confidence

that the money is
going to be available.

TOM PIOTROWSKI: So you've
been in town briefly

and you've been having
a lot of conversations

with some very sharp questions,
no doubt, being put to you.

What do you find
are the questions

that the big end of town
is asking you most often?

KEN BRINSDEN: Yeah, we get a lot
of questions about the approvals
process in Quebec.

Having been exposed to Quebec
and the James Bay region

for over a couple
of years now, I

would say it's a
good jurisdiction.

And we can be confident in
the progress of the approvals.

As long as we're a sensible
company presenting quality work

and deeply engaged
with the Cree,

you can expect a reasonable
and timely development process.

So we're looking
forward to that.

But nonetheless, it
elicits lots of discussion.

The second-order
sort of question

would be the development
of the industry.

And when I look at what's
already happening in the US

and Europe, and the build
that is already underway,

the commitment to
tens of billions

of dollars worth of expenditure
in gigafactories, I would say,

we don't really need to
worry about the demand side.

And for that matter, the
behaviour in the supply chain is

one to indicate that they're
all motivated to achieve that
localization criteria.

And hence, we're confident about
that aspect of the development
of the industry as well.

TOM PIOTROWSKI: Ken, we could
really go on for much longer

than we have available
today in terms of time.

But it's a great privilege to
be able to talk to you again.

And thank you very
much for your time.
KEN BRINSDEN: My pleasure, Tom.
Thanks for having me.

TOM PIOTROWSKI: And thank
you very much for joining us
for the Executive Series.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

LITHIUM (PRICE | SUPPLY | DEMAND) FORECA.summary:
<guideline>
주요내용: 리튬 산업의 장기 성장 전망과 Patriot Battery Metals의 Corvette 프로젝트에 대한 긍정적인 평가

내용:

- 지난 10년간 중국이 리튬 산업을 주도했지만, 이제는 미국과 유럽이 주도권을 가지게 될 것으로 전망
- 리튬 가격의 변동성이 있었지만, 장기적으로 리튬 수요는 계속 증가할 것으로 예상
- PATRIOT BATTERY METALS의 CORVETTE 프로젝트는 규모와 품위 면에서 세계적인 수준의 리튬 자원으로 평가
- 북미 시장에 근접하고 기존 인프라가 잘 갖춰져 있어 개발이 유리할 것으로 예상
- 중국 의존도를 낮추고 미국과 유럽의 자국 내 공급망 구축이 중요한 과제로 대두
- 최근 정부 지원 등으로 금융권의 리튬 산업 투자 분위기가 개선되고 있음

수요/공급에 대한 영향: 리튬 수요 증가 - 전기차 및 에너지 저장 시스템 수요 증가 // 리튬 공급 증가 - PATRIOT BATTERY METALS의 CORVETTE 프로젝트 개발 등으로 공급 확대 예상
</guideline>

HL_summary.주요내용: 리튬 산업이 2024년부터 2028년까지 미국과 유럽에서 큰 성장을 보일 것으로 예상되며, 이는 새로운 기가팩토리 건설에 의해 주도될 것이다.
내용: 캐나다의 Patriot's Corvette 프로젝트가 이러한 서구 지역의 증가하는 수요를 공급할 수 있는 유리한 위치에 있다.
Patriot사는 세계 최대 리튬 생산업체인 Albemarle사와의 전략적 파트너십을 통해 광산 생산량을 북미 내 새로운 화학 시설에 연결하고자 한다.
HL_summary.수요/공급에 대한 영향: 새로운 기가팩토리 건설로 인해 미국과 유럽의 리튬 수요가 크게 증가할 것으로 예상되며, Patriot사의 Corvette 프로젝트가 이러한 수요를 충족시킬 수 있을 것으로 보인다.

snippet.title: I Killed the Kings Lithium battery...
snippet.description: 6 months ago, i purchased a Kings 100ah 12V Lithium battery, i've taken it away on our big 4x4 trip, and well now its dead.

comments.textOriginal: Kudos to you for being impartial and honest in this video.  Most people would have simply blamed the Kings quality for the issue.  Respect. ✊  NOTE: Check the lithium battery spec of each brand before buying another one, as not all lithium batteries can be mounted at any which way.  Some must be mounted vertical only.  The warranty will be void if mounted any other way.

just a quick point on this battery regarding configuration. It's configured in 4s2p.2 packs of  4 batteries in series paralleled together. Each pack is nominally 3.2 volts 3.2 x 4 =12.8 volts. 
You'd have noticed the single  pack had 55aH written on the side of it. Parallel 2 for 110aH.
Fire from a lithium battery resembles that of a mega angry oxy acetylene torch on steroids and the  smoke from a lithium fire is really bad due to the toxins in it like cobalt and hydrogen fluoride.
Interesting video, thanks for sharing.
build your own, would make a great video.

You were asking a lot puting it under the vehicle - I'm surprised it didn't get staked as well. When I saw you place the battery in the build video, I wondered how long it would last - not long at all, it turned out. Just get another one and throw it inside. Use that spot for a water tank or something.
🤣 Not gonna lie.. That explosion made me jump watchin with surround sound headphones on hahaha
You could give another Kings battery a go but mount it in a different location, away from the elements 👍

If you want to waste more money on Kings batteries, the 100A Slim are in stock $399 on clearance, so they must have a newer model coming, brands are up to you, I would be going up to a 200A so it gives you more options, and mount it inside the canopy.

You guys like experimenting, buy another kings slimline $399 and fully incase it in silicone. You only need a few cheap tubes of silicone and make it 5mm thick all the way around, leaving the terminals clear. When it is set put it in the same spot and connect the wires and silicone over them. Just to see how well it lasts. If you put one inside it means rewiring and sealing the floor of the canopy. I have two kings 120ah in parallel and they are great. Keep the great videos coming. 😃👍

That was never going to last where it was mounted, even vibration would have killed that eventually. I would just get another Kings one, but the sealed cell type (prismatic). Mount it in the cab or tool box and keep it dry. A few years ago I had a different brand of battery in a battery box in my tray. I thought it was well sealed, however it wasn't and water got in and it must have seeped through the terminals or a joint somewhere. It did take a year to fail though. When it was pulled apart it had lots of individual cells that looked like D size batteries all spot welded with strips of metal in a series parallel arrangement. Anyway the cells all tested evenly, so it all got some WD40 and a brush clean, then a new BMS and it's been running fine INSIDE my tool box for another 3 or 4 years since. Mine get strapped down with lots of foam under them just to keep vibrations down as well. Thanks for pulling it apart to let us see what's inside. And always wear gloves/glasses/PPE when dealing with this sort of stuff, you only get one set of lungs and 2 eyes and they don't grow back.

It's interesting to see what's inside the Kings Lithium battery.  I currently have a Kings AGM aux battery and 6yrs on, it's still going strong.  So I'm seriously considering a Kings Lithium to replace it soon.   The explosion b-roll shown as Liam inserted the knife into the cell was priceless. 🤣 Good one boys. 👍

I've built a couple of Lithium Batteries and have just started my 3rd. It's not hard to do. See Andy's videos on Off Grid Garage. Has links to the best places to get the cells and BMS. Pretty crazy opening up that cell, even it being discharged. At least wear some safety gear, gloves and glasses. Love the videos. Cheers

Great video boys. If you get another kings, maybe run some silicone around the joins before you install ??
One other thing, I would recommend wearing safety classes when you open up the cell just in case.

That battery is Lithium Iron Phosphate. It's much more stable than a lithium ion battery in your phone (or anything with Cobalt in the mix). You could probably drill through those cells and everything would be fine. Even if it did catch fire, they don't run away like lithium ion does, it would probably smoke, but as it doesn't produce oxygen as it burns, it's a fairly mild experience and would likely not produce enough heat to burn the adjacent cell.

Their chemical stability is the primary reason they're used in residential applications. Also orientation of the cells/BMS doesn't matter, outside of case construction and water ingress considerations.

A conversation starter and a half this video is. 

I bought a 100AH from custom lithium. They’re based in Brisbane. 

The build quality is superior to the budget options I was considering. 

I mounted mine behind seat. Weighs 11kg. I’ve had it 12 months now and is used everyday powering a fridge.

Great video and plenty of questions! I think the days of folks building their own batteries are somewhat over. There seems to be more price parity between the cells and a BMS plus box etc and a finished product, unless you have a special use case or need something quite different to the commercail options. Be good to know whether you think the size etc you had is what you'd go for again? If not, and you don't mind spending a bit more then DIY. It'll be fun and we'll all learn loads!

Get another kings and mount either in the same spot, seal it and see if it does it again or mount upright somwhere and see if it has any issues. I think most people are more interested in seeing how well budget stuff holds up over time. I myself am watching closely as I wanted to do a small kings power system and your battery was the one I was looking at for my car too.
I dont think I could ever trust a home made one 😅

If you're going to go the route of building your own, you could effectively make it work inside the canopy to not take up a whole lot of room and still make it easy to disconnect when you want to lift the canopy off at any stage, plus it will keep it protected from the elements. Something to consider anyway and would make for an interesting project. 😎
Great to see your budget builds, unlike some of the sponsored channels out there.  Throw another Kings battery in there and test it to the limits again for us
I’d love to see you build one on the channel 👍
Perfect video to start a good Sunday morning

Interesting video, though the 8 cells are in a 4S2P (4 series 2 parallel ) configuration. 

Each pair of cells are in parallel (so the voltage remains the same but the capacity Ah doubles) and those 4 pairs are in series to get the nominal 12.8v.

Each cell should be 3.2v 50Ah .

It would be interesting to see you guys custom build a Lifepo4 battery.

As an FYI regarding lithium battery fires, it's not a matter of water getting to the lithium that creates the fire it's when there is a defect (naturally occuring or puncture) that creates a short circuit path for the massive stored energy to be released much like a welding arc but with a lot more energy that then makes the defect worse and so on until the stored energy is released. 
Water ingress can create shorts when the lithium salts and water combine with the electrodes.
Honestly I reckon if you were in Vic all the time and it was mounted under the tray you’d be right but the salt water and under washer in QLD might’ve killed it

Great video. You are correct that there is no required mounting orientation for that type of battery technology. Also, the battery probably is “water resistant” as they claim, but of note water resistant is a measure of how much water ingress you can get depending on water pressures applied to the object. If you hit this with high pressure water, e.g. in an under body car wash, or hitting a water crossing at speed, then the water pressure will exceed the water resistance of the packaging. But again, great video, informative and fun to watch!
Definitely be keen to see a custom built one!  Great video as always boys!

It's 100% accurate that you can orientate a lithium battery any orientation. Other batteries have liquid, hence that rule. 
I have mine on their ends.
You should try and make your own Liam. Buy a new bms. Would be interesting to see. There's a lot of people that do.
Be great to see you build a lithium battery. Keep up the good content fellas, love your work.

Build your own. See Andy from Offgrid Garage in QLD. He has some great recommendations and good testing data. You could quite easily make a 330AH battery. I have recently built myself a 300AH LIFEPO4 battery for my camper trailer. You can also pick a BMS that will give you a better current draw than then kings one.

💯 I’d love to see you build your own battery 
It’s very intriguing watching this one 
Keep up the good work lads 👍🏽
Bro is so chill when a 400$ battery just broke

I have been using a Solarking battery for 3 years now. Relatively cheap. We have it mounted in a cheap plastic battery box and bounced it across the country,  shorted it out, overloaded it etc. Not much more $ than a Kings.
If your not running induction cookers and coffee machines, maybe see if you can fit two sealed duel purpose lead acids or  agms under the tray - just a thought  (have to keep them upright probably)

I agree they could have run silicone around it but I am surprised you didn't do that yourself considering the mounting location.
I would have also used an enclosed mounting box with no top and sealed it with rubber seals against the bottom of the truck tray to fully protect it from the environment and a breather tube like a diff breather.
Great video, you don't try to blame everyone but yourself for the problem though.
We all learn from our mistakes, and I've made a few over the years.

ATG are good mid-range batteries. Prismatic cells, Bluetooth, good bms and assembled in Aus! I really rate mine. 

Would be good to see a battery build with costings too.

I reckon build your own battery, either with pre-made prismatic, or 18650’s?

Or go with another kings, I’m sure Patty can vouch for them by now given the price, it also went for 399 yesterday. 

Suits the theme of the channel more, budget, DIY style.
Was the BMS facing the chassis or facing the ground? I wonder if it was facing the chassis if it would not be lying in puddles of water then.

Good vid!

Considering how quickly the BMS rusted, I wonder if the underbody carwash recirculates salty water, or if they use fresh water?

First up, a very fair and balanced assessment of the Kings battery. Whilst building your own would be an interesting video, if you want a reliable, Australian made battery, itechworld batteries (and inverter) have severed me well.
I recon a custom built unit would make for a super awesome episode. I also however reckon checking out the kickass stuff. Mine have been awesome 👍

Great video guys. Good to see the battery is basically good and decently made. My Kings 120Ah lithium battery I reviewed a year or so ago is still going strong and I reckon these batteries are excellent value. My buddy bought the 200Ah and rates it highly too. Maybe get another and weatherproof it yourself?

awesome vid once again! i reckon you should build your own cause that would be really good to see, or buy another kings and build a sealed battery box if you mount it under the tray again, thats another awesome thing about lithium, they don't need to vent🥳 so seal her up!😁
Definitely interested in seeing you build your own battery! Could even keep the kings box to trick people 😂

Thanks for the video. I was contemplating pulling the trigger on one of these exact batteries to mount in almost the exact same location😅 At least I know it'll need a full IP rated enclosure around it now haha don't know if I would trust just siliconing the join
Awesome vid guys I would love to see you guys make one
awesome stuff guys very very  interesting what's in side one of them ... big thumbs up 👍😃👍

VOLT-X BLADE no its not waterproof  but 100ah with 200amp draw.
Been using mine since 2020 and still going strong.

Apart from where you mounted it there maybe more to orientation than you think. You should take a look at Tim Bates 4wd adventures and see his vid on his experience on mounting slim line lithium horizontally. Went through 2 batteries in 11 months and they were mounted under back seat. Keep up the great content. Really enjoyed your trip up north.
Verry informative Thankyou ❤

Buy an AO Lithium 100ah $348 on sale atm. This has a 200A 10sec bms, however, one youtuber ran it @ 200 for the entire discharge cycle. You can easily safely run a 2000w inverter of one of these - you cannot do that with a single kings battery.
And, the AO has bluetooth with onboard current and soc monitoring. For $348 it is a no brainer.
I'm 4 years in with a Lifepo4 from ANTPAK in Bayswater. It's been awesome. I think 400 for a 120a lithium. Mounted in my canopy...

Being an auto sparky, I’d advise against going anywhere near cheap lithiums again.
In my experience the DCS 200AH slimline is the go to battery.

You could get more capacity in a smaller footprint by building ur own inside the canopy, if you do go this route I would suggest a JK BMS.
Also do you realise you do still have 4 good 52A cells you could use to make a smaller portable battery as a spare.
Look into the kickass stuff man quality seems to be alot better than the kings stuff ive had both.

I reckon give the Kings another shot, especially if you were happy with it before it got saturated. I think you might be best to try and put a bead of silicon along the casing where it joins together and maybe put some kind of enclosure around the battery under your tray to try and avoid the same thing happening
I’ve got to say I’ve got 2 kings AGM batteries and they have lasted much longer than I thought they would
Great video lads!

Loved the cut to the explosion - well done to the editor - the timing was perfect.
That cell type is prone to kabooms, thankfully you opened a completely flat cell. Also without knowing what electrolyte it is handling its innards with bare hands....very risky. The "reason why women live longer than men" not just the chance of a kaboom, but also blood poisoning....I wonder if any nasties in the cell were absorbed through your skin absorbed into your bloodstream?

Get another kings and build a better box enclosure around it. 

How do you dispose of the used lithium batterie?
Build your own and show us the process. Very interested to see that
My ute came with the same size AGM in the position. Now that was fun to remove without a hoist.
Bloody lucky mate.. thank God it didn't catch fire or blast on ya.

No, 8 cells does not make a 12V battery. Nominal voltage per LiFePo4 cell is 3.2V and 4 in series or better presented as 4S is 12.8V.  That pack is 4S2P, Four in series per pack and 2 packs in parallel. Each cell is a 50Ah unit. As for the reuse of S/H cells, load of bull. You are refering to batching where they are either gonna be A grade or lower grade.  
Biggest issue I have found with Lithgium storage is People and their Mates making assumptions....

Building your own would be an interesting video, but I’ll just say my 120ah Kickass lithium is a fantastic battery, holds charge extremely well and runs all my excessive gear (2 fridges, oven, 2000w inverter) like a champ!
suggest since in the area go to Pakenham and get a power Paul battery at least has a 180ah in slim and has active balancer and Bluetooth to  know what's going on with the cells and the bms

go with itech world, ive had great experiences with 2 of there 100ah lithium batteries, also they make slimline one that would go where the kings one was, or super slim ones that would actually fit in the cab of your patrol behind the seats

The itechworld slimline battery says its ip67 waterproof. Would be good to see you try that. I liked seeing the battery attached to the car and not canopy, but like many of us having no space in the cab or underbonnet.

Condensation could be an issue if mounted outside the vehicle,
Just get a std kings, place in a battery box and strap that in your canopy, that way you can easily use it went camping away from the car
I do this all the time

Use VOLTX. I have purchased a 200ah Lithium battery from them and they are excellent for quality and power output. However if your putting the battery outside the vehicle put it in a secure and sealed location where it wont be vibrating a lot and away from water. Next time just seal/protect the lithium battery however I am also not sure how well a lithium battery will go in a sealed environment but should be safer for the battery itself.

I'd love to see you build your own battery. Something different compared to the other channels... I need another battery for my canopy and still weighing up my options in terms of DIY or buy premade. Not affiliate whatsoever but have bought a battery from them. Oz company with 0 negative feedback selling lifepo4 batteries which I suggest checking out if you don't build your own: ATG batteries in WA (free delivery for purchase in addition for warranty returns should an issue occur). Cheers

Be careful with those salt water car wash stations.... I've always avoided them because I once heard it's a closed system and it recycles the water back through. So you just spraying salt water onto your car.... 
Anyone have more on this?

i built my own battery and its going good all the parts came to about $600 as of 2 years ago i would deffentaly have a go at making your own as its good to konw what is in the battery 
ps dont cheap out on a bms learnt that the hard way

Itech claim their slimline as waterproof, so presumable it's just a straight swap for the same location. Otherwise I can recommend ATG batteries and Powerpaul, powerpaul have a 175ah that fits in a standard battery box
Two choices I would go with is either buy the same battery and put into a new location, or up the price range to a different brand that is still a slimline style that does not have a built in DCDC.
Highly recommended renogy batteries
Definitely build your own mate would be great to see how to
Great video. Get another one and seal it this time. I think there's more to be learnt for the broader 4wd community rather than building one 😊

I fixed my lithium. but not a kings. different cells. had to replace bms. my cells were all good, only the bms got fried so i was lucky i guess. And i only did it myself cos i couldn't find a how to video. btw it was worth the attempt cos it only cost me $17.99 to fix it
BTW. If kings sold you a new battery but it has 2nd hand cells in it. I consider that not a breach of contract but deception by them. Your warranty should still be valid.
Time for an ATG lithium. Had mine for 18 months, it's flawless, Australian owned business and very well priced

Nothing are bead of silicone cant fix one of my friends mounted their Red Arc lithium battery in the same way on his D Max and the water got inside and killed it, luckily Red Arc replaced it when he got the new ones he ran a bead of Silicone around all the spots that we thought water could get in and it's been perfect ever since.
Buy an itechworld battery they are IPF68 rates for place like your underbody  - I use them in my 4x4 and Caravan and they work well
Good stuff boys
Get a kings and seal it with silicone before installing it. Can check the posts too if they are water tight.
Great video boys

I dare say you don’t have a 100ah battery to start with. The battery market was unregulated and only late last year did laws come in preventing the importation of unapproved batteries, so any of the dodgy ones that kings, itech, ect had already imported they were allowed to sell off. Itech we’re selling 100ah lithium batteries that just had 4 10ah cells and filled the bottom of the battery with sand to make up the missing weight.
Go knings again just keep it in a enclosed space haven’t had an issue with my 300amp
It would be interesting to see if you can make the kings case waterproof. Whilst you have it and its empty, you could try seal it up and even vac pressure test.

Not for marine use means no salt environment.
Not suitable for under bonnet means no high temperature exposure.
You need to get in touch with Aussie batteries  for your next one, they sell theirs with silicon around the lid and mount them in silicon

The warranty was voided the second you mounted it where you did. I know that if you took it into my local 4wdsupacentre store the manager bloke would've absolutely declined a warranty replacement because of that.
I reckon for sure get another kings one and seal around that join with silicone. See if you can kill it again!
Look into ATG lithium batteries, Australian company and Australian made. Decently priced too

Not trying to be mean at all but I reckon you guys should do a mechanics/ auto elec course and also always consult someone with experience in applicable areas too if you're going to make a video about it.
You're lucky this thing didn't catch fire. Just don't want anyone to get hurt or sued and definitely don't want to see 4x4s get destroyed either.

Mate I'm no auto sparky but I do have some understanding of 12v all I can say there must be some good protection inside that battery....count your lucky stars that the battery didn't short internally....man your lucky to not have a fire and burn your rig....if you use that particular battery again put it in the canopy because the way you had it installed there would be no insurance....otherwise mate no surprise a battery for the application your after to be installed under the tray will cost some bigger bikies.
It would be interesting to buy a new one and do your own sealing and see how long it lasts.. this time round..

I seen a blog on Tim bates YouTube channel where he laid a battery on its side and it shit itself, he said that he found out that you can't lay them on their side and changed his set up with battery upright
go custom. build a water proof casing for it. so you can still store it in those areas where its out the road

Do you think if you buy another Kings batt and run the silicon bread yourself, that it would prevent the same outcome? If so... do that.  You said it was a great battery. 
Cheers, dd
Time for a all spark IP68 rated lifepo4 battery from offroad living 😊❤️ ahaha, good video tho i was curious as to how long it was gonna last and how they were made

a very informative video,im still laughing at Patrick standing back,off camera ,telling you, stick the knife in.whats the worst that could happen.😂😂😂.so saying the battery was good until it wasn't,buy another and mount it in a dry spot.like in canopy, or build a WATERPROOF box for it.i cant see that laying it down would contribute to the demise of the battery.👍
Good one bloke 👍👍👍👍 very interesting

snippet.title: This Op Ed on Hybrids and Climate Annoyed Me (Editorial Rant)
snippet.description: acwj Automotive News had a guest Op-Ed Thursday breaking down their reasoning on why hybrids have no place in the future ...

caption.text: on Thursday May 16th Automotive news
released a commentary in oped talking
about saying let's stick to the science
when talking about hybrids and Emissions
reduction and
unfortunately well this
editorial kind of rubbed me the wrong
way so I want to go through it and talk
about it and give my commentary back on
it welcome back to all cars y'all I am
John and this oped was released uh today
as matter of fact it's by David seon I
believe I pronounced that correctly
professor of mechanical engineering at
Cambridge University now um because this
is biased it is an op-ed it is an
opinion piece I take I make I I I do not
question his credentials but I have a
different view of it and unfortunately
because it is an oped it is biased and
he changes his view he changes the
argument to try to prove his point along

little wrong so I want to give my own
opinion back on it and he starts with
this is that uh Toyota is of course
leaned heavily into hybrids and that
quote long-term hybrid strategy
continues paying dividends for customers
dealers investors and Mother Earth and
Toyota argues that there's a scarce
supply of lithium in the world so it's
better to hybridize many cars s instead
of just electrifying a a few and that
hybrids can reduce emissions further and
faster than electric vehicles alone now
David here wants to lean into quote the
science about whether that's true or not
but he kind of misses the forest for the
trees by the time you get to the end I
won't go through every single paragraph
in here but he he he changes the Target
and it's it's an argument you see a lot
from people who are trying to push
battery electric vehicles this whole
thing when you read it really feels like
well he's got an agenda and so the
problem with this is there isn't a
shortage of lithium lithium prices have
fallen dramatically because of over
Supply so he makes the point here that
Tesla is making 100% battery electric
vehicles other people are um so why
shouldn't Toyota well there's a major
flaw with this one of the arguments that
will come up from environmentalists is
that we need to move to battery electric
vehicles not only because of CO2
emissions but also because there is a

finding new ways and new pack pockets of

worried about it it's a false argument
and then he says consequently consumers
can choose freely whether to purchase a
hybrid or an EV and automakers can

half true the automakers can choose what
they
make but consumers in the future in the
very near future will not have a choice
on what they buy unless we push for them
to have that choice governments around
the world including our own are pushing
for either 50% or more battery electric
sales and they're making it
mandatory so telling me that we're free
to choose Now does not mean in 2030 or
2035 that that choice will still exist
that's another false argument about what
the future
holds but what we're supposed to be
talking about here is hybrids and
whether they help with emissions
reductions in the future so he uses a a
very common argument here is that the
scientific consensus is that EVS emit
less well tohe that's a cool phrase
greenhouse gases than all combustion
engines today uh in a mixed electric
grid and that is correct in my research
of electric vehicles I've read over and
over and over again and it's a little
bit of a shell game for them but if you
look at mining the materials building
the car the life cycle of it and the
recycle
even if your grid is not
fully renewable even if it's off coal
the battery electric vehicle is still
cleaner overall that is true I buy that
and I believe that at the beginning of a
battery electric vehicle's life it's
actually dirtier than a combustion
engine car it's only as the life
continues of that car that it begins to
win and it it begins to win big as a
matter of fact so I can't take any
argument with that except that he goes
on to say that when Toyota or any other
car company claims that hybrid
drivetrains can reduce emissions further
and faster than Eves can we know that's
objectively untrue people should be
calling out pseudo scientific claims
when they only damage the industry's
reputation and here is
where you see the bias play in he is
putting up a false argument that you
have the choice but if you don't have
the choice
battery electrics are the way to go
because plug-in hybrids are dirtier than
battery electrics and he goes into that
here in just a minute more detail about
it but that's a false argument because
we don't have that binary choice and so
the point is is that hybrids will
increase electrification and massively

massively decrease CO2 emissions because

he's arguing against hybrids so that
leaves us with an internal combustion

well there's large parts of the world

have said on this channel battery

we're allowing them to have an

electric that's what decreases the

else that's why hybrids are such a great

that while more efficient combustion or

emissions a little they can't reduce
emissions to Net Zero and that they
aren't enough to meet the Paris
temperature goals okay so let's set two
arbitrary standards and then claim that
anything other than what I'm pushing can
actually meet it give me a break a does
say this is interesting an EV releases Z
gram of CO2 per mile that's interesting
plugin hybrids 60 to 70 hybrids 100 to
120 or combustion Vehicles 200 to 210 G
of CO2 per mile well that proves my
point it would be better to have 10
people buy a plug-in hybrid and release
G than just one person buy an EV a
battery electric vehicle and release
zero when everybody else needs to buy an
internal combustion engine car his own
data backs up the premise of what Toyota
actually said what initiated his
commentary here is backing up what
Toyota actually said we can help the
environment
more by getting more hybrids on the road
instead of sitting around and waiting or
using government to force people to buy
battery electric vehicles now the next
one is the standard automakers must meet
in their Us in the US by 2032 is 85
Grand per mile now I think that's going
to change the industry and the union
everybody's pushing back on that as not
being reasonable because we have a goal
of limiting the rise in global
temperatures to 1.5°
C okay I don't want to Wade too deep
into the climate debate overall but they
picked two degrees and then they said no
it needs to be 1.5 well maybe three is
okay so anything they're doing in the
environmental the climate change
argument is not about stopping it it's
just limiting it a little bit and then
so they set a a relatively arbitrary
number and then complain that people
don't meet it I I just I don't buy this
I think it's the right thing to do to
move to hybrids to reduce CO2 emissions
and to to care about global warming but
setting these kind of arbitrary numbers
that aren't rolling it back they're
already saying the climate has changed
they're already saying we've got worse
Summers and worse storms and everything
else and saying well that's okay it's
going to go ahead and get worse but
we're just trying to limit that they're
not actually fixing any problems so
arguing for a more expensive technology
that doesn't meet people's Lifestyles
Across the Nation and across the world
because we're trying to hit the standard
that can't be hit it it's just it's just
ridiculous move people to hybrids and
drop the co22 emissions from
Transportation by
2/3 that's a win and then I love this
paragraph here it's crucial to
understand that these EPA regulations
just like those in the European Union
and the UK are technology neutral
there's no discrimination for or against
certain drivetrains it's just that when
you set an emissions
reduction selling hybrids won't reach
them well this this is the kind of
roundabout that technologists
intellectuals governments do we're not
telling you it is technology neutral we
don't care how you meet the standards we
are however going to set a standard that
only one technology will
meet enjoy your
choice this whole oped here really just
rubs me wrong because he he he talks
about lithium but then lithium supply
but we're overproducing he talks about

out there he argues not that they
shouldn't be there
but only people should choose battery
electric vehicles and that the standards
that have been set up for the
world only a battery electric vehicle
can make it so hybrids will make
everything better but we shouldn't do it
whole thing just bothers me now again I
don't know the man I don't question his
credentials I don't question the
veracity of his
beliefs but the whole argument here just
rubs me
wrong and
felt less like an opinion piece and more

comments.textOriginal: Ah yes, everything is because of climate change! Your house, your energy bill, your car! Give it to us and we'll solve climate change!
I think it’s great to call out people like this! Forcing absurdly expensive (and boring to me) EVs down our throats. If we don’t adapt, then we hate the Earth!
A great common-sense rebuttal to this editorial Jon.
Hybrid owner here. They work now. My neighbor has his wife follow him to the public charger in her ice car, drop off the ev at the charger, and then later drive him to pick it up.

We can talk about the pollution created when making a hybrid battery and eventual disposal, but think of all the emissions that did not get created because of it during its useful life. The savings has to be far beyond the costs.

EVs make sense to a lot of people, but not to everyone. Love my hybrid, would love an EV, but as a realist a hybrid was the best choice for my lifestyle.

As for the politics behind either, I admit I care far more about its impact on the owner and how it is to drive and maintain than anything else.
Who are we to determine what the correct global temperature should be? Nothing is constant over time, taking drastic efforts to reduce or remove CO2 may be exactly the wrong thing to do.

Absolutely agree with your assessment of this editorial and Toyota's position.  My company car just switched from a 2018 Ford Escape 1.5L turbo to a 2024 Toyota Rav4 Hybrid.  My average MPG went from 29.3 to 47.0.   That's an improvement of  60.4% with  no pugging in, zero pain and zero inconvenience.  If every car sold saved 60% on fuel use, it would equal much more fuel saved overall than 1 in 10 cars being electric.  I see hybrids and plug in hybrids as the smartest way to go.  If  the sale of new ICE vehicles are outlawed, a lot of people will be out of the new car market and will be buying used for many years to come.   Then watch used ICE car prices spike again!
Former miner here....

Not a bad take on this op-ed.  There aren’t a lot of unhappy Prius owners.  While I have two BEV’s, I truly believe the average American garage would be best served by having a BEV and a hybrid (or an ICE vehicle). As aI have three vehicles in a 2 person household, we are at 2 BEV’s and a full size truck.  As much as I vastly prefer the EV’s, I can’t see a day in the near future when I would want to limit myself to one fuel choice.  Eventually, that may change but IMO, letting BEV’s become the majority option should happen organically and at the will of the consumer.  OTOH, I don’t mind the government setting ambitious efficiency targets because that is a long term step toward greater prosperity and will drive innovation
interesting timing on this one, as i sit with my "old" 2015 car wondering if I keep it too long will i be forced to buy something I do not want? I hope not.

Chew on this Irony. I live in Chile, one of largest litium producers in the World; yet, I can't use an EV.  They sell them. I could afford one. The problem is I live and travel in parts of the country where the next power line might be 200 to 300 km away. Forget charging stations (300 to 1000 km between). There are no power lines. Even gas stations in the Patagonia can be few and far between on both the Argentina (if they have gas) and Chilean side. Yea, so it is going to be a while before that is an option for me. Now in theory, a hybrid could do the job. I am holding off on buying one, because they are significantly more expensive than a gas vehicle. I did however give a Toyota hybrid some serious consideration. I just prefer vehicles with easily sourced local parts and service. I have three Toyotas in my yard, that all have more less compatible parts. My mechanic and I knows how to work on all of them. An EV breaks down, I am shipping it on a (diesel) flatbed, thousand+ kilometers to get fixed, and shipped back. The parts, are all on the other side of the World. It would be weeks or months before I could drive my car again. So, I will let everyone else fully work all the bugs out of the EV system first; and, it is a system (suply chain, energy infrastructure, service, parts, regulations, etc).
PHEV's are better than nothing I suppose but studies in the EU have found that a large percentage of people stop bothering to plug in.

We're also not free to choose that the taxpayer is subsidizing these EV's.  Well stated criticisms Jon, and no, I'm not one of these people "against" EV's.  Far from it.  I think they have been adopted in the wrong way, in that cities should have been equipped first with infrastructure and frankly, we should still be using Lead Acid for such city vehicles as they are 100 percent recyclable.  Once LiPo batteries take over, longevity and risks will be drastically reduced.
I agree with your comment about setting a standard that only one type of car can meet. I believe it was Henry Ford who said you can have any color car you want as long as it is black.
Nothing we do will change anything, we have no control
There's no money in stopping (or curing) anything.

I completely agree with you. Thank you for calling out these propagandists. I’m just amazed how these EVangelists don’t consider applying the same arguments to defend ice cars. Like dismissing “oversupplied lithium” as sustainable while pointing out the shortfalls of “oversupplied petroleum”. I mean, these guys will not apply the same logic of criticizing ice and hybrids to EVs. Oh well, whatever these guys say, Toyota will continue to keep making money because they make what the MAJORITY of people, and not what the vocal minority wants. Let’s see what the free market decides. 

By the way, your shirt color is my favorite.

The real argument for hybrids, is the vast amount of miles driven by most people is local miles. Say under 20 mile trips. The run to the school or grocery store trips.  The hybrids gets people now, on electric for those short trips, often in urban areas where polution is most dangerous to humans now. The full EV technology is simply not there. Especially if in under 10 years you have a bricked vehicle that can not be repaired, or the repair costs is more than a replacement. Scrapping a car under 10 years old, is hardly conserving resources.
Agree Jon. My prediction on public adoption is Hybrid -->  Plug-in Hybrid ----then--> Electric (but never all cars).  My next car is likely PHEV which is best of both world.
I love your reaction videos and I think if you did the occasional or scheduled rant video, it would be a great addition to your channel.
Do you have a Link to the article in question so that I can understand fully the points you're making?

Jon, I agree with all of your arguments and that the op-ed guy is biased. I do have a concern that hybrids could be very expensive to maintain, however. ICE technology is becoming quite complex, which is already concerning, and then you essentially add another drivetrain to that, as well as the additional equipment to make them work together. That’s what has kept me from buying one to be honest. 

I’d like to see a return to making cars and propulsion technology a bit simpler. That will make new cars less expensive and therefore more accessible, and the net gain in getting many older more polluting vehicles off the road is also a win. They would also weigh less, be cheaper to maintain and more reliable. I think we’re going to pay the price for the complexity necessary to eke out the very last bit of efficiency from ICE drivetrains and surrounding them in an overweight, technology-laden package. Sadly, I think that ship has sailed though.
I agree with you 100%and have believed hybrids are the way to go for now😁👍👍

Link to the article (may be behind a paywall):
https://www.autonews.com/guest-commentary/toyotas-argument-hybrids-isnt-scientifically-sound
Cheers from the Pacific West Coast of Canada

From the sounds of the argument, all that guy wants is to force everyone into EVs regardless of how much it could potentially negatively impact their lives, plain and simple. 

I’m a little surprised you didn’t bring up Porsche developing synthetic fuel and Toyota investing in liquid hydrogen as alternatives to traditional ICE cars that reduce emissions while still retaining their characteristics. That, in my eyes, is a win win for all of us and I don’t think they should be just tossed aside without being given a chance to be applied
Thank you. Spot on!
Typical EVangelists and environMENTALists argument. He must have been paid off by some European auto or Chinese company that wants to paint Toyota and Japanese auto as a whole in a negative flight

Theoretically, lithium used for battery cells is infinitely recyclable. Capacity to do so hasn't stood up yet because there aren't enough end-of-life EVs yet.
 By definition, petroleum products burned as fuel is *gone* .
At the point that EV take over ICE, their battery is 10 years old and needs to be replaced.

BEV tailpipe emissions: 0 grams per mile.
PHEV tailpipe emissions when operated within battery range: 0 grams per mile.

Besides that, we should be thinking in terms of grams per year, not grams per mile.  A rarely-driven ICE vehicle doesn't emit much anyway, in which case tailpipe emissions are immaterial.

Finally, U.S. tax policy favors ever-larger houses that require large lots at ever-increasing distances from the employment centers.  Most new construction is for 3000+ square foot houses build on former farmland or pasture in the middle of nowhere, requiring new freeways or added lanes to handle all the new traffic. Taxpayers are forced to subsidize and therefore promote this excess consumption, while being told that we all need to start driving Teslas.

I don't like any modern vehicles. They're all disposable appliances. They're not made to last. They're made impossible for people to maintain themselves. Also, they're all ugly. They all look like they're from the transformers movies. There's too much unnecessary technology. There's no visibility. They might be safer for the occupants, but they're more dangerous for anyone not inside the vehicle. Because you can't see or hear anything around you 
Cameras and sensors don't replace seeing something with your eyes. 
To anyone who disagrees with me. You obviously only use vehicles for transportation. I am a car person. Cars are more than transportation to me. And there are millions of people who think like me. I care about the environment. But I also enjoy my cars

As long as the consumer, still has the ultimate choice and power, EV vehicles will not account for the majority of sales, in the near future.
The US electric grid and charging station infrastructure, is not currently large enough or capable enough. 
Practicality and cost to the consumer must be factored in.

⁠shouldn’t greater efficiency help everyone, regardless of fuel type?  I don’t necessarily disagree that short term prospects for prosperity look bleak but they have been much worse many times before.  This too shall pass- albeit like a kidney stone

I've always been annoyed by the whole climate change argument for EV adoption.  I don't wanna go all tin-foil hat but if I were in a think tank trying to figure out how to kill a disruptive product, I'd try really hard to come up with a way to polarize the people and make them argue about it. 
Also, I'm not in the least concerned about some far off in the future suggestion for mandatory EV ownership.  Again, if I were the president and wanted to secure a few extra votes I'd show the people how dedicated I am to the cause (any cause) by strongly suggesting legislation be passed WAY, WAY after I out of office.  And, if I were really thinking big, I'd get with the previously mentioned think tank and see if we could help each other.  
Anyway, I always enjoy your insights.

As an aside, have you driven a Tesla yet?  My wife and I bought a used one a few months ago.  We've put over 3000mi/month on it.  It has some odd-ball quirks that I wish I could make go away but it's easily the best car either of us have ever owned.
The grams of c02 per mile for a ev is flawed. Unless the power came from ferry dust there will be some carbon used to make the power.
EVs: 0 grams CO2/mile?  It's nice to know our energy grid produces zero CO2 emissions!😅🤣😂 Coal provides 20% and natural gas provides 40% of our ⚡

PHEVs and hybrids are a good start, when driven properly and engineered for efficiency, but I really think we need to move away from SUVs and trucks. If we’re gonna curb emissions, we should at least start there as they’re the biggest offender when it comes to CO2 emissions. End the separate fuel efficiency and emissions standards and treat trucks and SUVs as passenger cars . We’ve let this go on for far too long.

I have to dispute what you are saying. I live in South Africa and we have very dirty electricity. If you do the maths then you will find that an electric vehicle and a ICE vehicle's CO2 emissions are roughly the same per km, except manufacturing an ICE produces more CO2.
(battery electric has large crumple zones and a low center of gravity )
Hybrid is good but Toyota still using nickel metal battery rather use lithium-ion.
You misspelled $cience
All of it is detached from reality.  Humans making the assertion that everything revolves around 1 gas: CO2 (one of the lowest concentration gases in the atmosphere).

well if you want a hybrid Toyota does it the best as they've been developing theirs since the early 90s the prius debuted in Japan for the 97 model year and in the US for 2001 and then you got Corolla and Camry hybrids for 2006 model year so those are going into their 4th generation with 2025 model year and are going hybrid only its the 9th gen of the Camry sedan without counting the 2 gens of the Solara coupe/convertible oh and there's a Celica revival coming
Academics analyzing real-life engineered products & systems ends in total nonsense.

I agree that hybrids are better than buying ICE, however, I absolutely dont believe that we need hybrids as a stepping stone to the future of BEVs. Thats like saying that everyone first had to own a Blackberry before they could own a full blown smartphone. Toyota's argument is manufactured as they simply dont want to stop producing ICE based products. Much of which is also very political in Japan.
I like that shirt

As far as I am concerned every weather event today is blamed on climate change and that is just not so. Like the fires happening in BC and AB it has already been said that well over half of them where stupid humans . I personaly have not seen much in the way of climate change that I no of . Yes we had a mild winter but in my life time  of well over almost 70 years we have had mild winters before and we have had very hot summers as well as well we have had cool summers. I have a hard time beleveing scientists that are payed for by the goverment as to them telling the truth. I have listened to some independent scientists that have said almost the oppasite  so for me who is to be beleaved ? Warmer weather here in the north could be very addvantages as to have a longer growing season and in turn less need for as much winter heating meaning less CO2. Either way life is not going to end one way or the other the way they are pushing this climate change crap it seems that in the next 30 40 years were all going to pearish . That my friends is not going to happen. Please excuse the spelling errorers spelling was something that I could never master.

Much of the current oversupply of lithium is due to speculation in mining. It is being used for batteries, but not at nearly the levels predicted a decade ago. But huge lithium mines and processing facilities were built.
EV prophets figured a huge number of people would be switching to electric by now. Surprise! Most people who could only afford a used ICE car a few years ago, can still only afford another dino juice drinker. Even people buying new cars still prefer the options that come with having a traditional engine, even if it is sitting next to an electric one under the hood.
His argument that we have an oversupply of lithium, and other rare earths, so we should use it should be changed. The proper outlook should be "We currently have an oversupply" and we should be storing it until needed.
I agree hybrids are a viable option, at this stage of the EV transition, and will be for at least a decade, if not more.

Why are governments worldwide picking on motor cars?? When the transport sector of the world is a very small contributor to overall co2 output of the world, Industry ,food production (meat!) contributes far far more. Motor cars are an easy target and always have been, When these climate experts announce the co2 out put of the planet do they take into account how much is consumed by the planet?(plants ,trees,oceans etc etc) or god forbid how much co2 is spewed out by a volcano! I do wonder…..
You're right, he's wrong. Does he have an agenda? He's a French named smarty in the UK, all I'm gone say....

Golf carts are not the future.    With the rise in apartment dwellers in this increasingly expensive cost of living environment, it makes absolutely no sense to own a golf cart.    Where am I going to charge my golf cart?    How much more am I going to have to pay for that electricity to go off property to charge it?    How much of my life must I waste to recharge a golf cart to go the same distance a 40 mpg ICE car can go refueling in under 10 minutes?      It is simply a joke to think that golf carts are the answer as they present themselves.     The key point here is that golf carts will not be viable as a mainstream alternative until its 20%-80% charge range translates into over 350 miles and that recharge is 10 minutes or less.    My ICE car gets 45 mpgs, travels well over 500 miles on a tank, and takes less than 10 minutes to refuel.    Until a golf cart can meet that, there is no way in hell I'm going for an expensive alternative just because it supports the psuedo science of western manmade climate change.

Sorry don't agree with you. BEV are far better than Hybrid. Just thinking of 80% less moving parts. Better I mean way better not having a transmission. And not carrying around fuel that can ignite easier than a BEV. Toyota is wrong.

Hybrid and plug in hybrids are more practical until the infrastructure to accommodate a large volume of electric cars exists.  Perhaps a more realistic goal would be to focus on building our capacity to generate power from renewables over coal and natural gas.   The Chinese are already eating our lunch with this technology so we have to do this just to stay competitive.

If you try and implement that amount of ev sales without hybrids you’re just going to end up with some people driving their 2000s and 2010s models way into the 2040s and 2050s. Do EVs work for some people? Yes, especially if you own a house and can afford to install a charger in your garage. For everyone else it’s not yet. Say it’s the year 2035 and you’re looking for a used car, you’re not going to want a 5-10 year old EV with less range than the newer models. And if that’s all there is you’re just going to keep your car or buy an older Model. That’s why hybrids are a good stepping stone. If I was an environmentalist I’d much rather in 2035 have 20% of people driving electric 50% driving hybrid and 30% driving old gas cars. Compared to 25% electric 65% old gas cars and 10% hybrids. Give or take. Thanks for reading my rant.
We have likely reached 1.5C- and could reach 2C by 2040. The climate is changing rapidly- we will see a minimum of 2.5C

I dont want to get too deep into the climate thing because at the end of the day most people just go in circles with it, but EVs are pretty damn dirty. If youve seen the strip mines in places like Africa and parts of South America, we are literally cutting down forests and/ir destroying ecosystems to use patroleum-fueler machina to dig hundreds of feet to find the rare metals needed to construct these batteries, the manufacturing process is very energy intensive. On top of that currently there is no way to fully or even partially recycle modern EV batteries. Also, instead of buying a gas or even a hybrid car that can be driven for 10-20 years and 100s of thousands of miles, means we're not using energy to make so many new vehicles. An EV battery is good for MAYBE 150k mi, then youre stuck with a giant heavy piece of useless hazardous waste that cant be cleanly or completely recycled and have to pay thousands for a new battery that will only last you another 100k mi. Then of course the grid in most places is powered primarily by coal or natural gas, and our demand for electricity will undoubtedly increase as more and more EVs are charging on the grid. It would be a lot better if they could be charged during the day when solar energy can be the primary source or power (in CA during the day up to 80% of the grid's electricity is being generatee by solar) but thats wheb people are USING their cars so they charge them at night when less renewable energy is available when fossil fuels are powering the grid. These are all points that are never mentioned and considered, and they need to be if our governments are going to FORCE us to buy EVs exclusively in the future.

Saw a car reviewer vid on plug in hybrid and he suggest either ice or bev instead. His reasoning was u need 2 engines to use petrol and electricity respectively, small battery capacity and inefficiency due to the excess weight of both system and I think weaker engines again due to having 2 system. It certainly makes common sense and his vids didn’t suggest a ev agenda. 

I understand there are erev where u can use petrol to directly power the electric engine. I wonder if that’s a better system
The United Nations is full of crap.
